tool.name: Filter sequences by ID
tool.command: seq_filter_by_id.py -i "$input_file" -f "$input_file.ext" #if $output_choice_cond.output_choice=="both" -p $output_pos -n $output_neg #elif $output_choice_cond.output_choice=="pos" -p $output_pos #elif $output_choice_cond.output_choice=="neg" -n $output_neg #end if #if $adv_opts.adv_opts_selector=="advanced" and $adv_opts.strip_suffix -s #end if #if $id_opts.id_opts_selector=="tabular": ## TODO - Decide on best way to expose multiple ID files via the XML wrapper. ## Single tabular file, can call the Python script with either UNION or INTERSECTION -l UNION "$id_opts.input_tabular" "$id_opts.columns" #else -t "$id_opts.id_list" #end if

param.name: id_opts_selector
param.label: Filter using the ID list from

param.name: columns
param.label: Column(s) containing sequence identifiers
param.help: Multi-select list - hold the appropriate key while clicking to select multiple columns

param.name: id_list
param.label: List of sequence identifiers (white space separated)
param.help: You can use both spaces and new lines to separate your identifiers.

param.name: output_choice
param.label: Output positive matches, negative matches, or both?
param.option: Both positive matches (ID on list) and negative matches (ID not on list), as two files
Just positive matches (ID on list), as a single file
Just negative matches (ID not on list), as a single file

param.name: strip_suffix
param.label: Remove typical pair read name suffices when matching identifiers?
param.help: Will remove suffices including Illumina /1 and /2, Roche 454 .f and .r, and assorted Sanger names like .p* and .q*

tool.help:
**What it does**
By default it divides a FASTA, FASTQ or Standard Flowgram Format (SFF) file in two, those sequences with or without an ID present in the tabular file column(s) specified. You can opt to have a single output file of just the matching records, or just the non-matching ones.
Instead of providing the identifiers in a tabular file, you can alternatively provide them as a parameter (type or paste them into the text box). This is a useful shortcut for extracting a few sequences of interest without first having to prepare a tabular file.
Note that the order of sequences in the original sequence file is preserved, as is any Roche XML Manifest in an SFF file. Also, if any sequences share an identifier (which would be very unusual in SFF files), duplicates are not removed.
**Example Usage**
You may have performed some kind of contamination search, for example running BLASTN against a database of cloning vectors or bacteria, giving you a tabular file containing read identifiers. You could use this tool to extract only the reads without BLAST matches (i.e. those which do not match your contaminant database).
You may have a file of FASTA sequences which has been used with some analysis tool giving tabular output, which has then been filtered on some criteria. You can then use this tool to divide the original FASTA file into those entries matching or not matching your criteria (those with or without their identifier in the filtered tabular file).
**References**
If you use this Galaxy tool in work leading to a scientific publication please cite the following papers:
Peter J.A. Cock, Björn A. Grüning, Konrad Paszkiewicz and Leighton Pritchard (2013). Galaxy tools and workflows for sequence analysis with applications in molecular plant pathology. PeerJ 1:e167 http://dx.doi.org/10.7717/peerj.167
